Transitions for continuous time state transition model

CtstmTrans.Rd

Summarize health state transitions in a continuous time state transition model with parameters that were estimated using a multi-state model.

CtstmTrans

Format

R6Class object.

Fields

data

Data used to simulate health state transitions by treatment strategy and patient. Must be an object of class input_data. If params is a list of models, then data must contain a unique row for each treatment strategy and patient; if params is a joint model, then data must contain a unique row for each treatment strategy, patient, and transition.

params

An object of class params_surv or params_surv_list.

trans_mat

A transition matrix describing the states and transitions in a multi-state model in the format from the mstate package. See the documentation for the argument "trans" in msprep.

start_ages

The starting age of each patient in the simulation. Must be the same length as the number of patients in data. Used alongside max_age in sim_stateprobs() with type = "individual"; does not otherwise need to be specified.

death_state

The death state in trans_mat. Used with max_age in sim_stateprobs with type = "individual" and in IndivCtstm$sim_disease as patients transition to this state upon reaching maximum age; does not otherwise need to be specified. By default, it is set to the final absorbing state (i.e., a row in trans_mat with all NAs).

Methods

new(data, params, trans_mat, start_ages = rep(38, data$n_patients), death_state = NULL)

Constructor for the class.

hazard(t)

Predict the hazard functions for each health state transition.

  • t: A numeric vector of times.

cumhazard(t)

Predict the cumulative hazard functions for each health state transition.

  • t: A numeric vector of times.

,
sim_stateprobs(t, start_state = 1, max_t = 100, max_age = 100, clock = "reset")

Simulate health state probabilities as a function of time.

  • t: A numeric vector of times.

  • start_state: The starting health state. Default is the first health state.

  • max_t: Maximum number of time periods to simulate the model for. Default is 100.

  • max_age: Maximum age to simulate each patient until. Default is 100.

  • clock: Currently only supports "reset", which implies that the time-scale of the cumulative hazards depends on time in the present state.

check()

Input validation for class. Checks that fields are the correct type.

See also

create_CtstmTrans, IndivCtstm

Examples

library("flexsurv")
#> Loading required package: survival

# Simulation data
dt_strategies <- data.frame(strategy_id = c(1, 2, 3))
dt_patients <- data.frame(patient_id = seq(1, 3),
                          age = c(45, 50, 60),
                          female = c(0, 0, 1))

# Multi-state model with transition specific models
fits <- vector(length = 3, mode = "list")
dat <- data.frame(bosms3)
for (i in 1:length(fits)){
  fits[[i]] <- flexsurvreg(Surv(years, status) ~ 1, data = dat[dat$trans == i, ],
                           dist = "exp")
}
fits <- flexsurvreg_list(fits)
tmat <- rbind(c(NA, 1, 2),
              c(NA, NA, 3),
              c(NA, NA, NA))

# Simulation model
hesim_dat <- hesim_data(strategies = dt_strategies,
                        patients = dt_patients)
fits_data <- expand_hesim_data(hesim_dat)
transmod <- create_CtstmTrans(fits, data = fits_data, trans_mat = tmat,
                              point_estimate = TRUE)
head(transmod$hazard(c(1, 2, 3)))
#>    trans sample strategy_id patient_id t    hazard
#> 1:     1      1           0          0 1 0.1898667
#> 2:     1      1           0          0 2 0.1898667
#> 3:     1      1           0          0 3 0.1898667
#> 4:     2      1           0          0 1 0.0534576
#> 5:     2      1           0          0 2 0.0534576
#> 6:     2      1           0          0 3 0.0534576
head(transmod$cumhazard(c(1, 2, 3)))
#>    trans sample strategy_id patient_id t cumhazard
#> 1:     1      1           0          0 1 0.1898667
#> 2:     1      1           0          0 2 0.3797333
#> 3:     1      1           0          0 3 0.5696000
#> 4:     2      1           0          0 1 0.0534576
#> 5:     2      1           0          0 2 0.1069152
#> 6:     2      1           0          0 3 0.1603728
transmod$sim_stateprobs(t = c(0, 5, 10))[t == 5]
#>    sample strategy_id state_id t      prob
#> 1:      1           1        1 5 0.6666667
#> 2:      1           1        2 5 0.3333333
#> 3:      1           1        3 5 0.0000000
#> 4:      1           2        1 5 0.6666667
#> 5:      1           2        2 5 0.3333333
#> 6:      1           2        3 5 0.0000000
#> 7:      1           3        1 5 0.0000000
#> 8:      1           3        2 5 0.3333333
#> 9:      1           3        3 5 0.6666667
